image.altText: Shane Rattenbury speaks behind a host of media microphones.

items.synopsis: ACT Greens leader Shane Rattenbury has defended his office's handling of allegations of sexual misconduct made against backbencher Johnathan Davis.

title.children: ACT Greens leader Shane Rattenbury defends handling of sexual misconduct allegations against Johnathan Davis

image.altText: The woman's hands lie in her lap, she has pink nail polish and wears a leopard-print skirt.

items.synopsis: The woman who was choked by Tongan man Seti Moala in April last year speaks of the trauma she experienced both during the attack and again as the case went to trial.

title.children: This woman was choked by a man in a Canberra motel room. She says she wasn't given a fair trial

image.altText: Bill Shorten mid-sentence wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: The federal government agrees to all of the recommendations of the Robodebt royal commission, as it reveals investigations have commenced into 16 public servants connected to the scheme.

title.children: 16 public servants investigated over Robodebt scheme, as government formally responds

image.altText: An employee of DP World walking along the Melbourne wharves

items.synopsis: DP World is a global behemoth in shipping and logistics. But a cyber attack on its Australian operation has crippled some of our busiest ports in the busy lead up to Christmas.

title.children: Christmas is not cancelled — yet. But DP World's freight ransomware issue is stacking up problems

image.altText: Two adults stand with a child in a wheelchair.

items.synopsis: Organising a trip to Ballarat was no easy task for this Melbourne family because of 12-year-old Anuli's complex needs. When the outing finally happened, it ended in a way that left them "traumatised".

title.children: Chain hurled at girl in wheelchair, dad assaulted 400m from police station, but no emergency response

image.altText: The silhouette of several people, some holidng Palestinian flags

items.synopsis: Global Palestinian solidarity demonstrations are getting bigger, but whether taking to the streets will make a difference to government policy is up for debate, writes Riley Stuart.

title.children: When the crowd chants 'ceasefire now', this is why some governments remain 'deaf'

image.altText: The shell of a car that has burnt up

items.synopsis: Police say alcohol may have been a factor in multiple-fatality crash in Victoria's north-east that's believed to have killed four vegetable farm workers from the Pacific.

title.children: Farm workers believed to be victims of fiery Victorian crash

image.altText: a cricketer bowling

items.synopsis: The cricket gods have smiled on a club bowler after he bagged six wickets in the final over of a one-day match to snatch a miracle victory for his team.

title.children: Cricket hero makes history after taking six wickets in six balls

image.altText: Sam Kerr gets in front of a defender to prod the ball home

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr ends a quiet spell for Chelsea by getting back to her familiar prolific ways with a second goal of the Women's Super League season in their win at Everton.

title.children: Kerr hits the scoresheet again as Chelsea secure hold on top spot in WSL

image.altText: Eggplants crushed on the ground under a fallen metal structure.

items.synopsis: Farmers are calling for assistance to rebuild infrastructure and replant crops, with the impact on the supply of fruit and vegetables unclear at the moment.

title.children: Farmers pick up the pieces after a wild hail storm causes an estimated $50 million in losses

image.altText: A heavily pregnant woman wearing a brown top looks at her belly

items.synopsis: Rates of labour induction have increased substantially in recent years. Is it making childbirth safer — or have the scales tipped too far?

title.children: Bringing birth forward: What's driving Australia's rising induction rate?

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing a navy suit

items.synopsis: Dr Bush-Blanasi was a champion for Indigenous rights at both the local and national level — most recently as a key campaigner for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Northern Land Council chair Dr Bush-Blanasi dies aged 61

image.altText: Close up of medicinal cannabis plant being grown in a farm.

items.synopsis: The first-ever bill to create a legal recreational marijuana market in Australia was lodged in federal parliament earlier this year — but not all cannabis enthusiasts are on board with the proposal to legalise it.

title.children: Why marijuana users are worried corporations will replace drug dealers

image.altText: Two men in suits shaking hands, Parliament House and $100 notes in the background.

items.synopsis: Identified in Parliament House by their orange access passes, lobbyists are free to wander the halls, governed not by laws but by a code of conduct. But the standard of regulation in the industry has been deplored by both integrity experts and independent politicians.

title.children: In Canberra, the lobbyists outnumber the politicians. One MP is now proposing an overhaul to curb their influence

image.altText: A man in a blue long sleeve shirt with his hands on his face sitting on a couch

items.synopsis: With the festive season rapidly approaching, the last thing anyone wants is COVID-19. Here's some tips from the experts about how to get over an infection and back to normal quickly.

title.children: With COVID-19 cases rising close to Christmas, we spoke to experts about how to beat it and get back to normal

image.altText: Flames lap outside a window.

items.synopsis: A bushfire destroys at least two homes and forces two dozen people to shelter at a boat ramp overnight at the Tasmanian east coast community of Dolphin Sands.

title.children: Homes destroyed, locals shelter at boat ramp as bushfire hits Tasmanian beachside community

image.altText: A large cruise ship docks at a harbour

items.synopsis: A cruise liner that had been dealing with cases of COVID-19 and gastroenteritis has arrived in Adelaide with fewer than 10 people still sick.

title.children: 'Vomit smells everywhere': Cruise ship's COVID, gastro outbreaks declared over as passengers disembark in Adelaide

image.altText: Dozens of women and children sit at the back of a truck, peering through a grid side wall

items.synopsis: Two of northern Gaza's major hospitals say they have closed doors to new patients due to bombardment and lack of supplies, with staff warning patient deaths could follow. Israel says it is homing in on Hamas and the hospitals should be evacuated.

title.children: Hospitals begin to shut down as Israel says it is closing in on Hamas in Gaza City

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier, we shared the World Health Organization's update on the Al Shifa Hospital. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs estimates some 3,000 patients remain trapped in the hospital. They say two premature babies and 10 other patients have died since the power outage that started on November 11. The organisation also claim s three nurses have been killed and an estimated 15,000 displaced people remain in the hospital. Critical infrastructure including the oxygen station, water tanks, a cardiovascular facility and the maternity ward was damaged, the UN's office says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two babies, 10 patients dead in Al Shifa hospital: UN update

Critical infrastructure including the oxygen station, water tanks, a cardiovascular facility and the maternity ward was damaged, the UN's office says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brisbane protester Sameer was among thousands of Australians rallying this weekend either in support of Palestinian communities or Israeli ones. The proud Australian Palestinian says his siblings, cousins and other family members — including young children — all live in Gaza. He doesn't know whether they are alive or dead. "Many Palestinians here are going through the same pain like me," he says. "I am here to speak on [my family's] behalf, to tell our Australian government enough is enough, call for a ceasefire." In a separate Israeli rally, Shaina — whose grandparents were holocaust survivors — says the Jewish community is hurting. "Obviously I'm not going through what they're going through, but the sentiment is there," Shaina says. "For them and for a lot of Jewish people, this is a second Holocaust." Read the full story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Thousands of Australians attend separate pro-Israel and pro-Palestinian rallies

featuredLink.title: As Sameer stood in support of his homeland, he counted the hours since he last heard from his family in Gaza

In a separate Israeli rally, Shaina — whose grandparents were holocaust survivors — says the Jewish community is hurting.

"For them and for a lot of Jewish people, this is a second Holocaust."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The daughter of the only Australian to be killed in Hamas's terrorist attack on southern Israel says she will never see her mother's "beautiful smile" again. Galit Carbone was residing in an Israeli kibbutz near the Gaza border when Hamas stormed into her house and killed her on October 7. Now, daughter Nicole has returned to the scene of the massacre with ABC reporter Allyson Horn. "The bad guys that actually killed my mum, they've been in here, in my house, in my room," Nicole says. "She was everything to me. She was my best friend. "I never realised they were going to take away my mum. "I'm not going to see her good eyes again, beautiful smile." Watch the full video below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'She was everything to me': Daughter of Israeli Australian killed by Hamas tells ABC

children.content: The daughter of the only Australian to be killed in Hamas's terrorist attack on southern Israel says she will never see her mother's "beautiful smile" again.
Galit Carbone
was residing in an Israeli kibbutz near the Gaza border when Hamas stormed into her house and killed her on October 7.
Now, daughter Nicole has returned to the scene of the massacre with ABC reporter
Allyson Horn.
"The bad guys that actually killed my mum, they've been in here, in my house, in my room," Nicole says.
"She was everything to me. She was my best friend.
"I never realised they were going to take away my mum.
"I'm not going to see her good eyes again, beautiful smile."
Watch the full video below:

items.synopsis: Multimedia artist Roberta Joy Rich uses family memories and archival news footage to ask deep questions about the impact of apartheid policies in South Africa and Australia.

title.children: Art exhibition links apartheid with colonial Australia in Perth show

items.synopsis: Comedian Celeste Barber is no stranger to the absurdities of the fashion industry, but even she was taken aback to learn that some clothes – and the women who wore them – were policed in our nation’s past.

title.children: Celeste Barber on Australia's 'uncomfortable' fashion moment

image.altText: O'Neil stands at the despatch box, Anthony Albanese sitting behind her.

items.synopsis: Fearing that telecommunications companies have been left to manage their own cyber affairs with limited oversight, the home affairs minister imposes new reporting obligations in an attempt to prevent another Optus-style hack.

title.children: Optus and other telcos to be forced to report to government on how they manage cybersecurity

image.altText: ANZ

items.synopsis: Australian shares are down, led by a substantial drop in ANZ's share price as its full-year profit misses market forecasts. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ANZ shares smashed as $7.1b profit disappoints, RBA warns of 'bumpy' road to curb inflation, ASX slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With last week's rate hike by the RBA, you might think it's dictated what the banks should charge mortgage holders — but that's not quite how it works. Instead, the RBA announced it would be charging the banks an extra 0.25 percentage points of interest when it lends to them overnight, and it would pay the banks an extra 0.25 percentage points on their deposits with the RBA. But the deposits the banks hold at the RBA have blown out since the pandemic and they've been earning interest from them — meaning rate hikes are affecting us in more ways than just how much we're paying on our mortgages. Confused how it all works? Don't fret — Alan Kohler has given a full explanation in under two minutes of how it all works below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate hikes are costing us money in more ways than you may think

children.content: With last week's rate hike by the RBA, you might think it's dictated what the banks should charge mortgage holders — but that's not quite how it works.
Instead, the RBA announced it would be charging the banks an
extra 0.25 percentage points of interest when it lends to them
overnight, and it would
pay the banks an extra 0.25 percentage points on their deposits
with the RBA.

But the deposits the banks hold at the RBA have blown out since the pandemic and they've been earning interest from them — meaning rate hikes are affecting us in more ways than just how much we're paying on our mortgages.
Confused how it all works? Don't fret —
Alan Kohler
has given a full explanation in under two minutes of how it all works below:

document.caption: Usually the banks borrow money from the RBA, which is how the central bank controls interest rates. But the deposits they hold at the RBA have blown out since the pandemic and they've been earning interest from them.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The timing certainly isn't great, but the good news is that despite the cyber attack on DP World's systems, Christmas isn't cancelled — yet. But it is going to cause some major headaches for importers, retailers and Christmas shoppers, because the shipping giant moves around 40% of the nation's freight. Around 30,000 containers are stacking up at DP World's depots in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Fremantle — and it's led to a "perfect storm" hitting supply chains in the lead-up to the festive season. You can read more from business reporter Daniel Ziffer and Matt Bamford below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Christmas cancelled because of the cyber attack on DP World?

featuredLink.title: Christmas is not cancelled — yet. But DP World's freight ransomware issue is stacking up problems

children.content: The timing certainly isn't great, but the good news is that despite the cyber attack on DP World's systems, Christmas isn't cancelled — yet.
But it is going to cause some major headaches for importers, retailers and Christmas shoppers, because the
shipping giant moves around 40% of the nation's freight.

Around 30,000 containers are stacking up at DP World's depots in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Fremantle — and it's led to a "perfect storm" hitting supply chains in the lead-up to the festive season.
You can read more from
business reporter Daniel Ziffer
and
Matt Bamford
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ANZ is the latest bank to reveal a multi billion dollar profit, as borrowers continue to feel the pain from inflation and rising interest rates on their home loans. But ANZ's boss Shayne Elliott says while the bank has profited from higher rates, a surprisingly small number of customers are in mortgage stress. He's told the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan that of a million borrowers, only 2,000 are seeking help with their repayments — but acknowledged the ANZ may have to help in the coming months. You can listen to their full chat below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 🎧 Only a small number of borrowers are in mortgage stress, says ANZ's boss

items.synopsis: Eighty asylum seekers being held in immigration detention were released almost immediately following last week's High Court ruling that they were being kept unlawfully.

title.children: 80 asylum seekers in immigration detention released 'almost immediately' after High Court ruling

image.altText: Brett Yang and Eddy Chen as young boys, sitting, holding violins.

items.synopsis: Brisbane violinists Brett Yang and Eddy Chen left coveted orchestra jobs to pursue YouTube stardom. This is how the duo built a social media audience of 7.5 million.

title.children: How two Brisbane violinists became global disruptors of classical music

image.altText: A map of Antarctica with a squiggly line surrounding it.

items.synopsis: The powerful Antarctic Circumpolar Current in the Southern Ocean acts like a force field, keeping warmer waters out of the polar region. But scientists are concerned a "gateway" is opening up.

title.children: The world's most powerful current has a 'leak' – and that spells trouble for Antarctica

image.altText: Alex's mum believes the ward's environment is not therapuetic

items.synopsis: An alleged violent altercation between a patient and one or more security guards that left other vulnerable patients shaken again puts safety at Perth Children's Hospital under the spotlight.

title.children: Investigation launched after alleged violent altercation at children's hospital leaves patients scared

image.altText: Screenshot of a video of a lion standing on a street

items.synopsis: Lion handler Rony Vassallo says he personally checked on the cage an hour before the lion went walkabout, and "everything was in order".

title.children: Escaped Italian circus lion 'didn't even for a second' want to attack nearby residents, says trainer

image.altText: people sitting around on top of mound of rubble with few standing buildings visible behind them

items.synopsis: Hamas says it is suspending hostage talks due to Israel's attacks around Al Shifa hospital, as the first group of foreigners and injured Palestinians to be evacuated from Gaza after the Rafah border crossing reopened arrive in Egypt.

title.children: Hamas suspends hostage negotiations due to their claims that Israel is targeting hospitals

image.altText: Two men in suits, Ian Cook and Ben walking past buildings in the Melbourne CBD.

items.synopsis: Ian Cook, of Melbourne caterer I Cook Foods, says it's a "bittersweet victory" after a Supreme Court judge ruled the business was unfairly shut down following a listeria outbreak in 2019.

title.children: 'Bittersweet' court victory for business owners in 'slug gate' listeria outbreak saga

image.altText: Woman in pink t-shirt adjusts a floral wreath on her head

items.synopsis: Heartbreak High actor and disability rights advocate Chloé Hayden has taken a step back from Instagram, due to abuse affecting her mental and physical health.

title.children: Actor and advocate Chloé Hayden is leaving Instagram, citing 'inescapable abuse'

image.altText: picture of a polar bear on ice

items.synopsis: A study of a thousand glaciers in the area shows the rate of melting entering a new phase over the last two decades.

title.children: Melting of all Greenland's glaciers 'in full swing' as speed of ice thaw increases fivefold
